column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/severe-headaches-and-bad-anxiety-for-luke-goedeke/|“Severe Headaches” And “Bad Anxiety” For Luke Goedeke|The Week 1 concussion suffered by Bucs right tackle Luke Goedeke was no trivial traumatic brain injury. And yes
column2: every concussion is a traumatic brain injury. Goedeke missed four games and returned wearing the Guardian Cap available to NFL players
column3: though few use it. Goedeke’s good buddy Tristan Wirfs
column5: opened up about the situation to WDAE radio yesterday in New Orleans. “He was getting like really
column6: really severe headaches at night. Getting like real bad anxiety about it
column7: ” Wirfs said of Goedeke. “He wasn’t right yet. … I told him
column9: dude. Like this is your brain.’ And he wore the Guardian cap for a while.” Wirfs said Goedeke wasn’t too happy about wearing the Guardian Cap because he knew Wirfs would make fun of him. In typical locker room style
column10: Wirfs said he told Goedeke that sure he’d be made fun of but it’s too important to skip the extra production. “I still love you
column11: ” Wirfs said he told Goedeke. This is a good reminder of how things that go on behind the scenes from fans and media. Todd Bowles surely was asked multiple times if Goedeke was close to meeting the NFL’s concussion-return standard. And Bowles just said it was a day-to-day thing. Bowles never said Wirfs was suffering. “[Goedeke] was going through [it] there for a while
column12: ” Wirfs said. Joe’s not knocking Bowles
column13: just mentioning how player health is not always as it seems. Regardless
column14: the ending was happy for Goedeke
column15: who had a hell of a season when he returned. “He came and balled out. It was awesome
column16: ” Wirfs said. Ira Kaufman Talks Josh Grizzard Introduction
column18: And Much More |2025-02-07 10:43:00|287|41|5|Luke Goedeke|Goedeke's challenging recovery but successful return to football.|2|Concern for player health and safety

It had nothing to do with morning prunes or tennis elbow. Sage Ira said he departed team headquarters feeling even more confident that pending Bucs free agent receiver Chris Godwin would be on the Bucs’ 2025 roster. Why
column4: Kaufman wasn’t spilling the entire truth. But Joe can attest to seeing Kaufman speaking to Bucs executives and he mysteriously stepped away early from the private media sitdown chat held with Joe and some local scribes and new Bucs playcaller Josh Grizzard. Odd behavior
column5: and Kaufman wasn’t exiting the building. For many weeks
column6: Kaufman has been saying he expects a return of Godwin barring something unforeseen
column7: like an injury setback or a contender making Godwin a massive offer. So Joe had to take note of the heightened Kaufman confidence. column8: and specifically receivers. It’s common thought that the Packers need a true No. 1 receiver
column9: and Godwin has never filled that role in Tampa

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/tristan-wirfs-details-whirlwind-of-learning-that-liam-coen-left/|Tristan Wirfs Details “Whirlwind” Of Learning That Liam Coen Left|Roughly two weeks ago
column2: Tristan Wirfs and the rest of his Bucs offensive linemen and Baker Mayfield and their families got away to a tropical location to enjoy the sands and beach and clear waters of the Caribbean and/or the Bahamas. Then those Bucs had their vacation rudely interrupted. They noticed on social media that the Jags wanted to interview former Bucs offensive coordinator Liam Coen. Then Coen pulled out. He was staying. But wait! He’s in Jacksonville. The Bucs couldn’t get a hold of him. Now he’s the Jags head coach? Wirfs and his teammates were monitoring the events as they unfolded at their vacation spot. The Bucs and the Coen drama seemed like a surreal world away even though the updates were coming in fast and furious to their smartphones. “It was kind of crazy
column3: ” Wirfs told Ari Meirov of The33rdTeam  from what looked like the Super Bowl media center in New Orleans yesterday. “The whole O-line was together
column4: we went on a little trip. So we are all seeing it
column7: break wherever. “And then we saw [Coen] was back with the Bucs. And then we saw
column9: he’s in Jacksonville. And [the Bucs] tried to block something. “It was a whirlwind
column10: really.” And while a lot of Bucs fans are still angry at how Coen left
column11: it seems Coen was standup with his players. Wirfs said he called them on their vacation to fill them in on what was going on and why he took the Jags job. “And then he called us and told us he loves us and appreciates us
column12: ” Wirfs said. Wirfs made it clear to Meirov that he doesn’t hold any sort of grudge against Coen. He rhetorically asked how could anyone expect a guy to pass up a chance to reach his dream. “It’s a business
column13: ” Wirfs said. “You don’t know when you’re going to get an opportunity like that
column14: to live your dream to be a head coach
column15: is going to come around [again]. “We understood.” Wirfs still shakes his head at how it all went down and how quickly it happened. “Just seeing it [play out]
column16: it was like back and forth
column18: ” Wirfs said. “I wish [Coen] success. Nothing but the best.” Being the standup guy Wirfs is
column19: Joe expects Wirfs is sincere in his words. Ira Kaufman Talks Josh Grizzard Introduction

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/josh-grizzard-seems-to-be-channeling-a-little-bit-of-al-davis/|Josh Grizzard Seems To Be Channeling A Little Bit Of Al Davis|New Bucs offensive coordinator Josh Grizzard didn’t come out and say it
column2: but it sounded just a little bit to Joe yesterday like Grizzard has a touch of Al Davis in him. Davis
column3: the legendary owner of the Raiders
column4: often liked to brag how he would take the age-old football cliché “Take what the defense gives you” and turn it on its ear
column5: saying “We’ll take what we want.” Grizzard said he wants his offense to attack a defense in a variety of ways
column6: not just run and not just pass. In other words
column7: the Bucs want to take what they want… if they believe a defense is vulnerable to a specific playcall. Still
column9: he wants to run the ball because if a team can run effectively it rips the heart out of a defense. “At the end of the day
column11: ” Grizzard said. “We want to be physical because the trenches win. When you’re able to run the ball and you’re able to press on a defense for four quarters
column12: that’s what wins ballgames. “We also want to be [multifaceted]. It could be a week where we need to throw the ball more or we need to run the ball more.” Grizzard emphasized that a team cannot be pass-only or run-only. Injuries do and will happen. An offense has to be flexible in order to adjust to injured starters. “Like last year
column13: the guys get hurt and how do you have guys step up?” Grizzard explained. “With the scheme you saw last year
column14: we were able to change plays at the line of scrimmage. … By doing that
column15: we put the pressure on the defense.” Being equal parts dangerous on the ground and in the air keeps defenses guessing
column17: especially in the red zone. And winning in the red zone often leads to victories. Ira Kaufman Talks Josh Grizzard Introduction
